Text

PRESENT DAY

It was a summer evening ; the sun was setting ; the sky was blue still , but tinged with gold , as if a thin veil of gauze hung over it , and here and there in the gold - blue amplitude an island of cloud lay suspended . In [the fields]152-the fields the trees stood majestically caparisoned , with their innumerable leaves gilt . [Sheep]45-sheep and cows , pearl white and parti - coloured , lay recumbent or munched [their]153-their way through the half transparent grass . An edge of light surrounded everything . A red - gold fume rose from the dust on [the roads]154-the roads . Even [the little red brick villas on [the high roads]156-the high roads]155-the little red brick villas on the high roads had become porous , incandescent with light , and the flowers in [cottage gardens]157-cottage gardens , lilac and pink like cotton dresses , shone veined as if lit from within . Faces of [people standing at cottage doors or padding along [pavements]159-pavements]158-people standing at cottage doors or padding along pavements showed the same red glow as [they]158-people standing at cottage doors or padding along pavements fronted the slowly sinking sun .

[Eleanor]46-eleanor came out of [[her]46-eleanor flat]160-her flat and shut the door . [Her]46-eleanor face was lit up by the glow of the sun as it sank over [London]1-london , and for a moment [she]46-eleanor was dazzled and looked out over the roofs and spires that lay beneath . There were [people]161-people talking inside [[her]46-eleanor room]162-her room , and [she]46-eleanor wanted to have a word with [[her]46-eleanor nephew]163-her nephew alone . [North]47-north , [[her]46-eleanor brother]164-her brother [[Morris]48-morris 's son]165-morris 's son , had just come back from [Africa]2-africa , and [she]46-eleanor had scarcely seen [him]47-north alone . [So many people]166-so many people had dropped in that evening -- [Miriam Parrish]49-miriam parrish ; [Ralph Pickersgill]50-ralph pickersgill ; [Antony Wedd]51-antony wedd ; [[her]46-eleanor niece]167-her niece [Peggy]52-peggy , and on top of [them]166-so many people all , [that very talkative man]168-that very talkative man , [[her]46-eleanor friend]169-her friend [Nicholas Pomjalovsky]53-nicholas , whom [they]166-so many people called [Brown]54-brown for short . [She]46-eleanor had scarcely had a word with [North]47-north alone . For a moment [they]166-so many people stood in the bright square of sunshine that fell on the stone floor of [the passage]170-the passage . [Voices]55-voices were still talking within . [She]46-eleanor put [her]46-eleanor hand on [his]47-north shoulder .

" It 's so nice to see [you]47-north , "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor said . " And [you]47-north have n't changed . . . "[46-eleanor] [She]46-eleanor looked at [him]47-north . [She]46-eleanor still saw traces of [the brown - eyed cricketing boy in [the massive man]172-the massive man , who was so burnt , and a little grey too over the ears]171-the brown - eyed cricketing boy in the massive man , who was so burnt , and a little grey too over the ears . " [We]1317-we sha'n't let [you]47-north go back , "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor continued , beginning to walk [downstairs]173-downstairs with [him]47-north , " to [that horrid farm]1318-that horrid farm . "[46-eleanor]

[He]47-north smiled . " And [you]46-eleanor have n't changed either , "[47-north] [he]47-north said .

[She]46-eleanor looked very vigorous . [She]46-eleanor had been in [India]3-india . [Her]46-eleanor face was tanned with the sun . With [her]46-eleanor white hair and [her]46-eleanor brown cheeks [she]46-eleanor scarcely looked [her]46-eleanor age , but [she]46-eleanor must be well over seventy , [he]47-north was thinking . [They]174-they walked [downstairs]173-downstairs arm - in - arm . There were [six flights of stone steps]176-six flights of stone steps to descend , but [she]46-eleanor insisted upon coming all the way down with [him]47-north , to see [him]47-north off .

" And [North]47-north , "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor said , when [they]174-they reached [the hall]177-the hall , " [you]47-north will be careful . . . . "[46-eleanor] [She]46-eleanor stopped on [the doorstep]178-the doorstep . " Driving in [London]1-london , "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor said , " is n't the same as driving in [Africa]2-africa . "[46-eleanor]

There was [[his]47-north little sports car]179-his little sports car outside ; [a man]180-a man was going past the door in the evening sunlight crying " Old chairs and baskets to mend . "[180-a man]

[He]47-north shook [his]47-north head ; [his]47-north voice was drowned by the voice of [the man]181-the man crying . [He]47-north glanced at a board that hung in [the hall]177-the hall with names on it . Who was in and who was out was signified with a care that amused [him]47-north slightly , after [Africa]2-africa . The voice of [the man]181-the man crying " Old chairs and baskets to mend , "[181-the man] slowly died away .

" Well , good - bye , [Eleanor]46-eleanor , "[47-north] [he]47-north said turning . " [We]1319-we shall meet later . "[47-north] [He]47-north got into [[his]47-north car]184-his car .

" Oh , but [North--]5-north-- "[185-she] [she]185-she cried , suddenly remembering something [she]185-she wanted to say to [him]47-north . But [he]47-north had turned on the engine ; [he]47-north did not hear [her]185-she voice . [He]47-north waved [his]47-north hand to [her]185-she -- there [she]185-she stood at the top of the steps with [her]185-she hair blowing in the wind . [The car]186-the car started off with a jerk . [She]185-she gave another wave of [her]185-she hand to [him]47-north as [he]47-north turned the corner .

[Eleanor]46-eleanor is just the same , [he]47-north thought : more erratic perhaps . With [a room full of [people]161-people]187-a room full of people -- [[her]185-she little room]189-her little room had been crowded -- [she]185-she had insisted upon showing [him]47-north [her]185-she new shower - bath . " [You]47-north press that knob , "[185-she] [she]185-she had said , " and look-- "[185-she] Innumerable needles of water shot down . [He]47-north laughed aloud . [They]190-they had sat on the edge of the bath together .

But [the cars]191-the cars behind [him]47-north hooted persistently ; [they]191-the cars hooted and hooted . What at ? [he]47-north asked . Suddenly [he]47-north realised that [they]191-the cars were hooting at [him]47-north . The light had changed ; it was green now , [he]47-north had been blocking the way . [He]47-north started off with a violent jerk . [He]47-north had not mastered the art of driving in [London]1-london .

The noise of [London]1-london still seemed to [him]47-north deafening , and the speed at which [people]161-people drove was terrifying . But it was exciting after [Africa]2-africa . [The shops]193-the shops even , [he]47-north thought , as [he]47-north shot past rows of plate- glass windows , were marvellous . Along [the kerb]194-the kerb , too , there were barrows of fruit and flowers . Everywhere there was profusion ; plenty . . . . Again the red light shone out ; [he]47-north pulled up .

[He]47-north looked about [him]47-north . [He]47-north was somewhere in [Oxford Street]6-oxford street ; [the pavement]195-the pavement was crowded with [people]161-people ; jostling [each other]197-each other ; swarming round the plate - glass windows which were still lit up . The gaiety , the colour , the variety , were amazing after [Africa]2-africa . All these years , [he]47-north thought to [himself]47-north , looking at a floating banner of transparent silk , [he]47-north had been used to raw goods ; hides and fleeces ; here was the finished article . A dressing - case , of yellow leather fitted with silver bottles , caught [his]47-north eye . But the light was green again . On [he]47-north jerked .

[He]47-north had only been back ten days , and [his]47-north mind was a jumble of odds and ends . It seemed to [him]47-north that [he]47-north had never stopped talking : shaking hands ; saying How - d'you - do ? [People]161-people sprang up everywhere ; [[his]47-north father]199-his father ; [[his]47-north sister]200-his sister ; [old men]201-old men got up from armchairs and said , [You]47-north do n't remember [me]0-i ? [Children]202-children [he]47-north had left in [the nursery]203-the nursery were [grown- up men at college]204-grown- up men at college ; [girls with pigtails]205-girls with pigtails were now [married women]206-married women . [He]47-north was still confused by it all ; [they]161-people talked so fast ; [they]161-people must think [him]47-north very slow , [he]47-north thought . [He]47-north had to withdraw into the window and say , " What , what , what do [they]161-people mean by it ? "[47-north]

For instance , this evening at [[Eleanor]46-eleanor 's]207-eleanor 's there was [a man there with a foreign accent who squeezed lemon into [his]208-a man there with a foreign accent who squeezed lemon into his tea tea]208-a man there with a foreign accent who squeezed lemon into his tea . Who might [he]208-a man there with a foreign accent who squeezed lemon into his tea be , [he]47-north wondered ? " [One of [[Nell]56-nell 's dentists]1321-nell 's dentists]1320-one of nell 's dentists , "[52-peggy] said [[his]47-north sister]200-his sister [Peggy]52-peggy , wrinkling [her]52-peggy lip . For [they]161-people all had lines cut ; phrases ready - made . But that was [the silent man on the sofa]210-the silent man on the sofa . It was the other one [he]47-north meant -- squeezing lemon in [his]208-a man there with a foreign accent who squeezed lemon into his tea tea . " [We]161-people call [him]54-brown [Brown]54-brown , "[52-peggy] [she]52-peggy murmured . Why [Brown]54-brown if [he]54-brown 's [a foreigner]211-a foreigner , [he]47-north wondered . Anyhow [they]161-people all romanticized solitude and [savagery--"I]212-a little man called pickersgill wish [I]212-a little man called pickersgill 'd done what [you]47-north did , "[212-a little man called pickersgill] said [a little man called [Pickersgill]50-ralph pickersgill]212-a little man called pickersgill -- except this man [Brown]54-brown , who had said something that interested [him]47-north . " If [we]161-people do not know [ourselves]161-people , how can [we]161-people know [other people]1322-other people ? "[54-brown] [he]54-brown had said . [They]161-people had been discussing [dictators]213-dictators ; [Napoleon]57-napoleon ; the psychology of [great men]214-great men . But there was the green light--"GO "[47-north] . [He]47-north shot on again . And then [the lady with the ear - rings]215-the lady with the ear - rings gushed about the beauties of Nature . [He]47-north glanced at the name of [the street on the left]216-the street on the left . [He]47-north was going to dine with [Sara]58-sara but [he]47-north had not much notion how to get [there]217-there . [He]47-north had only heard [her]58-sara voice on the telephone saying , " Come and dine with [me]58-sara -- [Milton Street]7-milton street , fifty - two , [my]58-sara name 's on the door . "[58-sara] It was near [the Prison Tower]8-the prison tower . But [this man]218-this man [Brown]54-brown -- it was difficult to place [him]218-this man at once . [He]218-this man talked , spreading [his]218-this man fingers out with the volubility of [a man who will in the end become a bore]219-a man who will in the end become a bore . And [Eleanor]46-eleanor wandered about , holding a cup , telling [people]161-people about [her]46-eleanor shower- bath . [He]47-north wished [they]221-they would stick to the point . [Talk]59-talk interested [him]47-north . Serious talk on abstract subjects . " Was solitude good ; was society bad ? "[59-talk] That was interesting ; but [they]221-they hopped from thing to thing . When [the large man]222-the large man said , " Solitary confinement is the greatest torture [we]221-they inflict , "[222-the large man] [the meagre old woman with the wispy hair]223-the meagre old woman with the wispy hair at once piped up , laying [her]223-the meagre old woman with the wispy hair hand on [her]223-the meagre old woman with the wispy hair heart , " It ought to be abolished ! "[223-the meagre old woman with the wispy hair] [She]223-the meagre old woman with the wispy hair visited [prisons]224-prisons , it seemed .

" Where the dickens am [I]47-north now ? "[47-north] [he]47-north asked , peering at the name on [the street corner]225-the street corner . [Somebody]226-somebody had chalked a circle on the wall with a jagged line in it . [He]47-north looked down [the long vista]227-the long vista . Door after door , window after window , repeated the same pattern . There was a red - yellow glow over it all , for the sun was sinking through the [London]1-london dust . Everything was tinged with a warm yellow haze . Barrows full of fruit and flowers were drawn up at [the kerb]194-the kerb . The sun gilded the fruit ; the flowers had a blurred brilliance ; there were roses , carnations and lilies too . [He]47-north had half a mind to stop and buy a bunch to take to [Sally]58-sara . But [the cars]191-the cars were hooting behind [him]47-north . [He]47-north went on . A bunch of flowers , [he]47-north thought , held in the hand would soften the awkwardness of meeting and the usual things that had to be said . " How nice to see [you]58-sara -- you've filled out , "[58-sara] and so on . [He]47-north had only heard [her]58-sara voice on the telephone , and [people]161-people changed after all these years . Whether this was [the right street]231-the right street or not , [he]47-north could not be sure ; [he]47-north filtered slowly round the corner . Then stopped ; then went on again . This was [Milton Street]7-milton street , [a dusky street]232-a dusky street , with [old houses]233-old houses , now let out as [lodgings]234-lodgings ; but [they]235-they had seen better days .

" The odds on that side ; the evens on this , "[47-north] [he]47-north said . [The street]236-the street was blocked with [vans]237-vans . [He]47-north hooted . [He]47-north stopped . [He]47-north hooted again . [A man]180-a man went to the horse 's head , for it was a coal - cart , and the horse slowly plodded on . [Fifty - two]239-fifty - two was just along the row . [He]47-north dribbled up to the door . [He]47-north stopped .

A voice pealed out across [the street]236-the street , the voice of [a woman singing scales]241-a woman singing scales .

" What [a dirty]1323-a dirty , "[47-north] [he]47-north said , as [he]47-north sat still in [the car]186-the car for a moment-- here [a woman]243-a woman crossed [the street]236-the street with a jug under [her]243-a woman arm--"sordid , "[47-north] [he]47-north added , " [low - down street to live in]1324-low - down street to live in . Pargiter]63-s. pargiter was near the top , punched on a strip of aluminium . [He]47-north rang one of the many bells . [No one]245-no one came . [The woman]246-the woman went on singing scales , mounting slowly . The mood comes , the mood goes , [he]47-north thought . [He]47-north used to write poetry ; now the mood had come again as [he]47-north stood there waiting . [He]47-north pressed the bell two or three times sharply . But [no one]245-no one answered . Then [he]47-north gave the door a push ; it was open . There was a curious smell in [the hall]177-the hall ; of vegetables cooking ; and the oily brown paper made it dark . [He]47-north went up the stairs of what had once been [[a gentleman]249-a gentleman 's residence]250-a gentleman 's residence . The banisters were carved ; but they had been daubed over with some cheap yellow varnish . [He]47-north mounted slowly and stood on [the landing]251-the landing , uncertain which door to knock at . [He]47-north was always finding [himself]47-north now outside the doors of [strange houses]252-strange houses . [He]47-north had a feeling that [he]47-north was [no one]245-no one and nowhere in particular . From across [the road]254-the road came the voice of [the singer]255-the singer deliberately ascending the scale , as if the notes were stairs ; and here [she]255-the singer stopped indolently , languidly , flinging out the voice that was nothing but pure sound . Then [he]47-north heard [somebody inside]256-somebody inside , laughing .

That 's [her]255-the singer voice , [he]47-north said . But there is [somebody]226-somebody with [her]255-the singer . [He]47-north was annoyed . [He]47-north had hoped to find [her]255-the singer alone . The voice was speaking and did not answer when [he]47-north knocked . Very cautiously [he]47-north opened the door and went in .

" Yes , yes , yes , "[58-sara] [Sara]58-sara was saying . [She]58-sara was kneeling at the telephone talking ; but there was [nobody there]258-nobody there . [She]58-sara raised [her]58-sara hand when [she]58-sara saw [him]47-north and smiled at [him]47-north ; but [she]58-sara kept [her]58-sara hand raised as if the noise [he]47-north had made caused [her]58-sara to lose what [she]58-sara was trying to hear .

" What ? "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said , speaking into the telephone . " What ? "[58-sara] [He]47-north stood silent , looking at the silhouettes of [[his]47-north grandparents]259-his grandparents on the mantelpiece . There were no flowers , [he]47-north observed . [He]47-north wished [he]47-north had brought [her]58-sara some . [He]47-north listened to what [she]58-sara was saying ; [he]47-north tried to piece it together .

" Yes , now [I]58-sara can hear . . . . Yes , [you]58-sara 're right . [Someone]1325-someone has come in . . . . Who ? [North]47-north . [[My]58-sara cousin from [Africa]2-africa]1326-my cousin from africa . . . . "[58-sara]

" [You]47-north 've met [him]1326-my cousin from africa ? "[58-sara] [she]58-sara was saying . There was a pause . " D'you think so ? "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said . " Yes . Called [Brown]54-brown , "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said , pushing up a chair for [him]47-north .

[He]47-north remembered the attitude ; [she]58-sara came back in sections ; first the voice ; then the attitude ; but something remained unknown .

" [You]58-sara 've not changed , "[47-north] [he]47-north said -- the face [he]47-north meant . A plain face scarcely changed ; whereas beautiful faces wither . [She]58-sara looked neither young nor old ; but shabby ; and [the room]261-the room , with the pampas grass in a pot in the corner , was untidy . [A lodging - house room]262-a lodging - house room tidied in a hurry [he]47-north guessed .

" And you-- "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said , looking at [him]47-north . This half knowing [people]161-people , [this half being known]264-this half being known , this feeling of the eye on the flesh , like a fly crawling -- how uncomfortable it was , [he]47-north thought ; but inevitable , after all these years . The tables were littered ; [he]47-north hesitated , holding [his]47-north hat in [his]47-north hand . " What picture ? "[47-north] [he]47-north asked .

" The one who sits looking puzzled with [his]265-the puzzled man in the picture hat in [his]265-the puzzled man in the picture hand , "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said . [He]47-north put [his]47-north hat on the table , but awkwardly . A book fell to the floor .

" Sorry , "[47-north] [he]47-north said . [She]58-sara meant , presumably , when [she]58-sara compared [him]47-north to [the puzzled man in the picture]265-the puzzled man in the picture , that [he]47-north was clumsy ; [he]47-north always had been .

" This is n't [the room where [I]47-north came last time]1331-the room where i came last time ? "[47-north] [he]47-north asked .

[He]47-north recognised a chair -- a chair with gilt claws ; there was the usual piano .

" No -- that was on [the other side of [the river]1333-the river]1332-the other side of the river , "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said , " when [you]47-north came to say good - bye . "[58-sara]

[The house]310-the house was quiet now , save for the sound of the bath water running away . A watery pattern fluctuated on the ceiling . [She]52-peggy ran [her]52-peggy eye from thing to thing . " [We]587-we must -- [we]587-we must ! "[71-renny]

" [I]58-sara am ready , "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said , looking at [them]596-them .

" [We]596-them must go-- "[58-sara] [she]58-sara said , turning to [[her]58-sara sister]597-her sister .

[She]58-sara put the book on the table ; [she]58-sara gave it a sad little pat as [she]58-sara shut it .

" [We]596-them must go , "[58-sara] [she]58-sara repeated , and followed [them]596-them down [the stairs]401-the stairs .

[Maggie]52-peggy rose . [She]52-peggy gave one more look at [the cheap lodging - house room]599-the cheap lodging - house room . There was the pampas grass in its terra - cotta pot ; the green vase with the crinkled lip ; and the mahogany chair . On the dinner table lay the dish of fruit ; the heavy sensual apples lay side by side with the yellow spotted bananas . It was an odd combination-- the round and the tapering , the rosy and the yellow . [She]52-peggy switched off the light . [The room]261-the room now was almost dark , save for a watery pattern fluctuating on the ceiling . In this phantom evanescent light only the outlines showed ; ghostly apples , ghostly bananas , and the spectre of a chair . Colour was slowly returning , as [her]52-peggy eyes grew used to the darkness , and substance . . . . [She]52-peggy stood there for a moment looking . Then a voice shouted :

" [Maggie]52-peggy ! [Maggie]52-peggy ! "[548-the maid]

" [I]52-peggy 'm coming ! "[52-peggy] [she]52-peggy cried , and followed [them]596-them down [the stairs]401-the stairs .

" [Miss Margaret Pargiter]81-miss margaret pargiter , "[52-peggy] said [Peggy]52-peggy .

" [Miss Margaret Pargiter]81-miss margaret pargiter ! "[548-the maid] [the maid]548-the maid called out into [the room]261-the room .

[She]52-peggy went in ; but [she]52-peggy felt plated , coated over with some cold skin . [They]596-them had come too early -- [the room]261-the room was almost empty . And [Milly]104-milly said , " Tut - tut - tut , "[47-north] [North]47-north observed .

It sounded like the half- inarticulate munchings of animals in [a stall]810-a stall . [Tut - tut - tut]107-tut - tut - tut , and [chew - chew - chew]811-chew - chew - chew -- as [they]812-they trod out the soft steamy straw in [the stable]813-the stable ; as [they]812-they wallowed in [the primeval swamp]814-the primeval swamp , prolific , profuse , half - conscious , [he]47-north thought ; listening vaguely to the good - humoured patter , which suddenly fastened itself upon [him]47-north .

" What d'you weigh , [North]47-north ? "[815-his uncle] [[his]47-north uncle]815-his uncle was asking , sizing [him]47-north up . [He]815-his uncle looked [him]47-north up and down as if [he]47-north were a horse .

" [We]812-they must get [you]47-north to fix a date , "[104-milly] [Milly]104-milly added , " when [the boys]1623-the boys are [home]392-home . "[104-milly]

[He]47-north was sinking ; [he]47-north was falling under [their]812-they weight ; the name in [his]47-north pocket even was fading . Could nothing be done about it ? " [D'you]46-eleanor know what time it is , [Eleanor]46-eleanor ? "[52-peggy] said [Peggy]52-peggy , coming up to [them]885-them . [She]52-peggy pointed to [her]52-peggy watch . " Do n't [you]46-eleanor think it 's time to be going ? "[52-peggy] [she]52-peggy said .

Yet there it hung before [her]52-peggy , the thing [she]52-peggy had seen , the thing [she]52-peggy had not said . But as [she]52-peggy fell back with a jerk against the wall , [she]52-peggy felt relieved of some oppression ; [her]52-peggy heart thumped ; the veins on [her]52-peggy forehead stood out . [She]52-peggy had not said it , but [she]52-peggy had tried to say it . Now [she]52-peggy could rest ; now [she]52-peggy could think [herself]52-peggy away under the shadow of [their]940-their ridicule , which had no power to hurt [her]52-peggy , into [the country]505-the country . [Her]52-peggy eyes half shut ; it seemed to [her]52-peggy that [she]52-peggy was on [a terrace]791-a terrace , in the evening ; an owl went up and down , up and down ; its white wing showed on the dark of the hedge ; and [she]52-peggy heard [country people]943-country people singing and the rattle of wheels on [a road]944-a road .

Then gradually the blur became distinct ; [she]52-peggy saw the line of the bookcase opposite ; the wisp of muslin on the floor ; and two large feet , in tight shoes , so that the bunions showed , stopped in front of [her]52-peggy .

For a moment [nobody]690-nobody moved ; [nobody]690-nobody spoke . [Peggy]52-peggy sat still . [She]52-peggy did not want to move , or to speak . [She]52-peggy wanted to rest , to lean , to dream . [She]52-peggy felt very tired . Then more feet stopped , and the hem of a black skirt .

" Are n't [you]52-peggy people coming down to supper ? "[52-peggy] said a chuckling little voice . [She]52-peggy looked up . It was [[her]52-peggy aunt]362-her aunt [Milly]104-milly , with [[her]104-milly husband]731-her husband by [her]104-milly side .

" [We]949-they must go , "[46-eleanor] said [Eleanor]46-eleanor . Wait , wait , [Peggy]52-peggy wanted to implore [her]46-eleanor . " [I]46-eleanor 'm sorry to be such [an old muddler]1676-an old muddler , "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor apologised . [She]46-eleanor shook a cushion ; coins rolled out onto the floor . A sixpenny bit spun on its edge across the carpet , reached a pair of silver shoes on the floor and fell flat .

[A handsome elderly woman , with curled white hair and something shining in]953-a handsome elderly woman , with curled white hair and something shining in [her]953-a handsome elderly woman , with curled white hair and something shining in hair was standing in the doorway looking round [her]953-a handsome elderly woman , with curled white hair and something shining in , as if [she]953-a handsome elderly woman , with curled white hair and something shining in had just come in and were looking for [[her]953-a handsome elderly woman , with curled white hair and something shining in hostess]954-her hostess , who was not there . " [Kitty]92-kitty ! "[46-eleanor] [Eleanor]46-eleanor repeated . [She]46-eleanor went towards [her]953-a handsome elderly woman , with curled white hair and something shining in with [her]46-eleanor hands stretched out . [They]955-they all got up . [North]47-north was glad to go ; but where was [he]47-north to go now ? [He]47-north wanted to hear what [they]1054-all these people were saying ; but not to be drawn in [himself]47-north . [He]47-north listened . [They]1054-all these people were arguing . Politics and money , [he]47-north said to [himself]47-north ; money and politics . That phrase came in handy . But [he]47-north could not understand the argument , which was already heated . Never have [I]0-i felt so lonely , [he]47-north thought . The old platitude about solitude in [a crowd]1062-a crowd was true ; for hills and trees accept one ; [human beings]997-human beings reject [one]309-one . [He]47-north turned . [A nice fresh - faced boy with a freckled nose in ordinary day clothes]1086-a nice fresh - faced boy with a freckled nose in ordinary day clothes was looking at [him]47-north . [People]161-people met , [he]47-north thought , pretending to read , in [hired halls]1093-hired halls . And one of [them]161-people stood on [a platform]1094-a platform . There was the pump - handle gesture ; the wringing - wet- clothes gesture ; and then the voice , oddly detached from [the little figure]1095-the little figure and tremendously magnified by the loudspeaker , went booming and bawling round [the hall]177-the hall : Justice ! [Liberty]132-liberty ! For a moment , of course , sitting among knees , wedged in tight , a ripple , a nice emotional quiver , went over the skin ; but next morning , [he]47-north said to [himself]47-north as [he]47-north glanced again at [the house]310-the house - [agents]1098-agents ' placard , there 's not an idea , not a phrase that would feed a sparrow . What do [they]1098-agents mean by Justice and Liberty ? [he]47-north asked , all [these nice young men with two or three hundred a year]1099-these nice young men with two or three hundred a year . If [they]1098-agents want to reform [the world]1339-the world , [he]47-north thought , why not begin there , at the centre , with [themselves]1098-agents ? [He]47-north turned on [his]47-north heel and ran straight into [an old man in a white waistcoat]1101-an old man in a white waistcoat .

" [Hullo]67-hullo ! "[47-north] [he]47-north said , holding out [his]47-north hand .

It was [[his]47-north Uncle]815-his uncle [Edward]72-edward . [He]72-edward had the look of [an insect whose body has been eaten out , leaving only the wings , the shell]1103-an insect whose body has been eaten out , leaving only the wings , the shell .

" Very glad to see [you]47-north back , [North]47-north , "[72-edward] said [Edward]72-edward , and shook [him]47-north warmly by the hand .

" Very glad , "[47-north] [he]47-north repeated . [He]47-north was shy . [He]47-north was spare and thin . [He]47-north looked as if [his]47-north face had been carved and graved by a multitude of fine instruments ; as if it had been left out on a frosty night and frozen over . [He]47-north threw [his]47-north head back like a horse champing a bit ; but [he]47-north was an old horse , a blue - eyed horse whose bit no longer irked [him]47-north . [His]47-north movements were from habit , not from feeling . What had [he]47-north been doing all these years ? Yes , but [they]1104-they found it difficult to talk . [He]47-north had the air of being stamped , [North]47-north thought ; [he]47-north had kept something , after all , out of the hubbub .

" [I]47-north 'd like to brush up [my]47-north classics , "[47-north] [he]47-north said suddenly . " Not that [I]47-north ever had much to brush , "[47-north] [he]47-north added , foolishly , afraid of [the schoolmaster]1125-the schoolmaster .

[Edward]72-edward did not seem to be listening . [He]72-edward was raising [his]72-edward eyeglass and letting it fall , as [he]72-edward looked at the queer jumble . There [his]72-edward head rested with the chin thrown up , on the back of [his]72-edward chair . [The crowd]1126-the crowd , the noise , the clatter of knives and forks , made it unnecessary to talk . [North]47-north stole another glance at [him]72-edward . The past and poetry , [he]47-north said to [himself]47-north , that 's what [I]0-i want to talk about , [he]47-north thought . [He]47-north wanted to say it aloud . But [Edward]72-edward was too formed and idiosyncratic ; too black and white and linear , with [his]72-edward head tilted up on the back of [his]72-edward chair , to ask [him]72-edward questions easily .

Now [he]72-edward was talking about [Africa]2-africa , and [North]47-north wanted to talk about the past and poetry . There it was , [he]47-north thought , locked up in that fine head , the head that was like [a Greek boy]1127-a greek boy 's head grown white ; the past and poetry . Then why not prise it open ? Why not share it ? What 's wrong with [him]72-edward , [he]47-north thought , as [he]47-north answered [the usual intelligent Englishman]1128-the usual intelligent englishman 's questions about [Africa]2-africa and [the state of [the country]505-the country]1129-the state of the country . Because [he]72-edward 's [a priest]1131-a priest , [a mystery monger]1132-a mystery monger , [he]47-north thought ; feeling [his]72-edward coldness ; this guardian of beautiful words .

But [Edward]72-edward was speaking to [him]72-edward .

"[47-north] And [he]47-north saw before [him]47-north [a house with [creeper - shaded rooms]1134-creeper - shaded rooms]1133-a house with creeper - shaded rooms , [butlers creeping]1135-butlers creeping , decanters , and some one handing a box of good cigars .

" How very kind of [you]47-north ! "[46-eleanor] said [Eleanor]46-eleanor , taking a glass . [He]47-north [himself]47-north took a glass of some yellow liquid . " Who 's [that pretty girl]1745-that pretty girl , "[72-edward] said [Edward]72-edward , inclining [his]72-edward head , " over there , standing in the corner , talking to [the youth]1746-the youth ? "[72-edward]

" Are n't [they]1746-the youth lovely ? "[46-eleanor] said [Eleanor]46-eleanor . " Just what [I]46-eleanor was thinking . . . . [Everyone]320-everyone looks so young . That 's [[Maggie]52-peggy 's daughter]1748-maggie 's daughter . . . . But who 's that talking to [Kitty]92-kitty ? "[46-eleanor]

" That 's [Middleton]137-middleton , "[72-edward] said [Edward]72-edward . " What , do n't [you]46-eleanor remember [him]137-middleton ? [You]46-eleanor must have met [him]137-middleton in the old days . "[72-edward]

[They]1137-their chatted , basking there at [their]1137-their ease . [Spinners]1138-spinners and sitters in the sun , [North]47-north thought , taking [their]1137-their ease when the day 's work is over ; [Eleanor]46-eleanor and [Edward]72-edward each in [[his]72-edward own niche]1139-his own niche , with [his]72-edward hands on the fruit , tolerant , assured .

[He]72-edward watched the bubbles rising in the yellow liquid . For [them]1137-their it 's all right , [he]72-edward thought ; [they]1137-their 've had [their]1137-their day : but not for [him]72-edward , not for [[his]72-edward generation]1140-his generation . For [him]72-edward a life modelled on [the jet]1141-the jet ( [he]72-edward was watching the bubbles rise ) , on the spring , of the hard leaping fountain ; another life ; a different life . Not halls and reverberating megaphones ; not marching in step after [leaders]1142-leaders , in herds , [groups]1143-groups , [societies]1088-societies , [caparisoned]1145-caparisoned . No ; to begin inwardly , and let [the devil take the outer form]1146-the devil take the outer form , [he]72-edward thought , looking up at [a young man with a fine forehead and a weak chin]1147-a young man with a fine forehead and a weak chin . Not black shirts , green shirts , red shirts -- always posing in the public eye ; that 's all poppycock . Why not down barriers and simplify ? But [a world]1148-a world , [he]72-edward thought , that was all one jelly , one mass , would be a rice pudding world , [a white counterpane world]1149-a white counterpane world . Again the speech was brought to the ground . [He]53-nicholas must be [a foreigner]211-a foreigner , [Kitty]92-kitty thought to [herself]92-kitty , because [he]53-nicholas has no self- consciousness . There [he]53-nicholas stood holding [his]53-nicholas wine - glass and smiling .

[He]72-edward drew [himself]72-edward back . No more speech - making for [me]0-i , [he]72-edward thought . [He]72-edward had [his]72-edward glass in [his]72-edward hand still . It was still half full of pale yellow liquid . The bubbles had ceased to rise . The wine was clear and still . Stillness and solitude , [he]72-edward thought to [himself]72-edward ; silence and solitude . . . that 's the only element in which the mind is free now .

Silence and solitude , [he]72-edward repeated ; silence and solitude . [His]72-edward eyes half closed themselves . [He]72-edward was tired ; [he]72-edward was dazed ; [people]161-people talked ; [people]161-people talked . [He]72-edward would detach [himself]72-edward , generalise [himself]72-edward , imagine that [he]72-edward was lying in [a great space on [a blue plain]1229-a blue plain with [hills on the rim of the horizon]1230-hills on the rim of the horizon]1228-a great space on a blue plain with hills on the rim of the horizon . [He]72-edward stretched out [his]72-edward feet . There were the sheep cropping ; slowly tearing the grass ; advancing first one stiff leg and then another . And babbling -- babbling . [He]72-edward made no sense of what [they]161-people were saying . Through [his]72-edward half - open eyes [he]72-edward saw hands holding flowers -- thin hands , fine hands ; but hands that belonged to [no one]245-no one . And were they [flowers the hands]1232-flowers the hands held ? Or [mountains]1233-mountains ? Blue mountains with violet shadows ? Then petals fell . Pink , yellow , white with violet shadows , the petals fell . They fall and fall and cover all , [he]72-edward murmured . And there was the stem of a wine - glass ; the rim of a plate ; and a bowl of water . [The hands]1234-the hands went on picking up flower after flower ; that was a white rose ; that was a yellow rose ; that was a rose with violet valleys in its petals . There they hung , many folded , many coloured , drooping over the rim of the bowl . And petals fell . There they lay , violet and yellow , little shallops , boats on [a river]1235-a river . And [he]72-edward was floating , and drifting , in a shallop , in a petal , down [a river]1235-a river into silence , into solitude . . . which is the worst torture , the words came back to [him]72-edward as if a voice had spoken them , that [human beings]997-human beings can inflict . . . .

[No idols]1238-no idols , [no idols]1238-no idols , [no idols]1238-no idols , [her]92-kitty laughter seemed to chime as if the tree were hung with innumerable bells , and [he]53-nicholas laughed too .

[Their]1241-their laughter ceased . Feet thudded , dancing on the floor above . A siren hooted on [the river]1333-the river . [A van]303-a van crashed down [the street]236-the street in the distance . There was a rush and quiver of sound ; something seemed to be released ; it was as if the life of the day were about to begin , and this were the chorus , the cry , the chirp , the stir , which salutes the [London]1-london dawn .

[Kitty]92-kitty turned to [Nicholas]53-nicholas .

" What 's very cheap ? "[46-eleanor] [Eleanor]46-eleanor murmured . [She]46-eleanor half opened [her]46-eleanor eyes . But where was [she]46-eleanor ? In [what room]1509-what room ? In which of [the innumerable rooms]1250-the innumerable rooms ? Always there were [rooms]1251-rooms ; always there were [people]161-people . Always from the beginning of time . . . . [She]46-eleanor shut [her]46-eleanor hands on the coins [she]46-eleanor was holding , and again [she]46-eleanor was suffused with a feeling of happiness . Was it because this had survived -- this keen sensation ( [she]46-eleanor was waking up ) and the other thing , the solid object -- [she]46-eleanor saw an ink - corroded walrus -- had vanished ? [She]46-eleanor opened [her]46-eleanor eyes wide . Here [she]46-eleanor was ; alive ; in [this room]926-this room , with [living people]1667-living people . [She]46-eleanor saw all the heads in a circle . At first [they]1255-they were without identity . Then [she]46-eleanor recognised [them]1255-they . That was [Rose]93-rose ; that was [Martin]88-martin ; that was [Morris]48-morris . [He]48-morris had hardly any hair on the top of [his]48-morris head . There was a curious pallor on [his]48-morris face .

There was a curious pallor on all [their]1255-they faces as [she]46-eleanor looked round . The brightness had gone out of the electric lights ; the table- cloths looked whiter . [North]47-north 's head -- [he]48-morris was sitting on the floor at [her]46-eleanor feet -- was rimmed with whiteness . [His]48-morris shirt - front was a little crumpled .

[He]48-morris was sitting on the floor at [Edward]72-edward 's feet with [his]48-morris hands bound round [his]48-morris knees , and [he]48-morris gave little jerks and looked up at [him]72-edward as if [he]48-morris appealed to [him]72-edward about something .

" [Uncle Edward]72-edward , "[48-morris] [she]46-eleanor heard [him]48-morris say , " tell [me]48-morris this . . . "[48-morris]

[He]48-morris was like [a child asking to be told a story]1256-a child asking to be told a story .

" Tell [me]48-morris this , "[48-morris] [he]48-morris repeated , giving another little jerk . " [You]72-edward 're [a scholar]1845-a scholar . About the classics now . [Aeschylus]143-aeschylus . [Sophocles]133-sophocles . [Pindar]144-pindar . "[48-morris]

[Edward]72-edward bent towards [him]48-morris .

" And the chorus , "[72-edward] [North]47-north jerked on again . [She]46-eleanor leant towards [them]1257-them . " The chorus-- "[47-north] [North]47-north repeated .

" [[My]72-edward dear boy]1622-my dear boy , "[72-edward] [she]46-eleanor heard [Edward]72-edward say as [he]72-edward smiled benignly down at [him]48-morris , " do n't ask [me]72-edward . [I]72-edward was never a great hand at that . No , if [I]72-edward 'd had [my]72-edward way"--he[72-edward] paused and passed [his]72-edward hand over [his]72-edward forehead--"I should have been . . . "[72-edward] A burst of laughter drowned [his]72-edward words . [She]46-eleanor could not catch the end of the sentence . What had [he]72-edward said-- what had [he]72-edward wished to be ? [She]46-eleanor had lost [his]72-edward words .

There must be another life , [she]46-eleanor thought , sinking back into [her]46-eleanor chair , exasperated . Not in dreams ; but here and now , in [this room]926-this room , with [living people]1667-living people . [She]46-eleanor felt as if [she]46-eleanor were standing on the edge of a precipice with [her]46-eleanor hair blown back ; [she]46-eleanor was about to grasp something that just evaded [her]46-eleanor . There must be another life , here and now , [she]46-eleanor repeated . This is too short , too broken . [We]1260-we know nothing , even about [ourselves]1260-we . [We]1260-we 're only just beginning , [she]46-eleanor thought , to understand , here and there . [She]46-eleanor hollowed [her]46-eleanor hands in [her]46-eleanor lap , just as [Rose]93-rose had hollowed [hers]93-rose round [her]93-rose ears . [She]46-eleanor held [her]46-eleanor hands hollowed ; [she]46-eleanor felt that [she]46-eleanor wanted to enclose the present moment ; to make it stay ; to fill it fuller and fuller , with the past , the present and the future , until it shone , whole , bright , deep with understanding .

" [Edward]72-edward , "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor began , trying to attract [his]1261-he attention . But [he]1261-he was not listening to [her]46-eleanor ; [he]1261-he was telling [North]47-north some old college story . It 's useless , [she]46-eleanor thought , opening [her]46-eleanor hands . It must drop . It must fall . And then ? [she]46-eleanor thought . For [her]46-eleanor too there would be the endless night ; the endless dark . [She]46-eleanor looked ahead of [her]46-eleanor as though [she]46-eleanor saw opening in front of [her]46-eleanor [a very long dark tunnel]1262-a very long dark tunnel . But , thinking of the dark , something baffled [her]46-eleanor ; in fact it was growing light . The blinds were white .

There was a stir in [the room]261-the room .

[Edward]72-edward turned to [her]46-eleanor .

" Who are [THEY]1264-two children ? "[1261-he] [he]1261-he asked [her]46-eleanor , pointing to the door .

[She]46-eleanor looked . [Two children]1264-two children stood in the door . [Delia]68-delia had [her]68-delia hands on [their]1264-two children shoulders as if to encourage [them]1264-two children . [She]68-delia was leading [them]1264-two children over to the table in order to give [them]1264-two children something to eat . [They]1264-two children looked awkward and clumsy .

[Eleanor]46-eleanor glanced at [their]1264-two children hands , at [their]1264-two children clothes , at the shape of [their]1264-two children ears . " [The children of [the caretaker]1848-the caretaker]1847-the children of the caretaker , [I]68-delia should think , "[68-delia] [she]68-delia said . Yes , [Delia]68-delia was cutting slices of cake for [them]1264-two children , and they were larger slices of cake than [she]68-delia would have cut had [they]1264-two children been [the children of [[her]68-delia own friends]1266-her own friends]1265-the children of her own friends . [The children]1267-the children took the slices and stared at [them]1267-the children with a curious fixed stare as if [they]1267-the children were fierce . But perhaps [they]1267-the children were frightened , because [she]68-delia had brought [them]1267-the children up from [the basement]1695-the basement into [the drawing - room]1269-the drawing - room .

" Eat it ! "[68-delia] said [Delia]68-delia , giving [them]1264-two children a little pat .

[They]1267-the children began to munch slowly , gazing solemnly round [them]1264-two children .

" Hullo , [children]202-children ! "[88-martin] cried [Martin]88-martin , beckoning to [them]1267-the children . [They]1267-the children stared at [him]88-martin solemnly .

" Have n't [you]1267-the children got a name ? "[88-martin] [he]88-martin said . [They]1267-the children went on eating in silence . [He]88-martin began to fumble in [his]88-martin pocket .

" Speak ! "[88-martin] [he]88-martin said . " Speak ! "[88-martin]

" [The younger generation]665-the younger generation , "[52-peggy] said [Peggy]52-peggy , " do n't mean to speak . "[52-peggy]

[They]1267-the children turned [their]1267-the children eyes on [her]52-peggy now ; but [they]1267-the children went on munching . " No school tomorrow ? "[52-peggy] [she]52-peggy said . [They]1267-the children shook [their]1267-the children heads from side to side .

" Hurrah ! "[88-martin] said [Martin]88-martin . [He]88-martin held the coins in [his]88-martin hand ; pressed between [his]88-martin thumb and finger . " Now -- sing a song for sixpence ! "[88-martin] [he]88-martin said .

" Yes . Were n't [you]88-martin taught something at [school]1066-school ? "[52-peggy] [Peggy]52-peggy asked .

[They]1267-the children stared at [her]52-peggy but remained silent . [They]1267-the children had stopped eating . [They]1267-the children were a centre of [a little group]1061-a little group . [They]1267-the children swept [their]1267-the children eyes over [the grown - up people]1271-the grown - up people for a moment , then , each giving [the other]1272-the other a little nudge , [they]1267-the children burst into song :

Etho passo tanno hai , [Fai]145-fai donk to tu do , [Mai]146-mai to , kai to , lai to see [Toh dom]1273-toh dom to tuh do--

That was what it sounded like . Not a word was recognisable . The distorted sounds rose and sank as if [they]1267-the children followed a tune . [They]1267-the children stopped .

[They]1267-the children stood with [their]1267-the children hands behind [their]1267-the children backs . Then with one impulse [they]1267-the children attacked the next verse :

Fanno to par , etto to mar , Timin tudo , tido , Foll to gar in , mitno to par , Eido , teido , meido--

[They]1267-the children sang the second verse more fiercely than the first . The rhythm seemed to rock and the unintelligible words ran themselves together almost into a shriek . [The grown - up people]1271-the grown - up people did not know whether to laugh or to cry . [Their]1271-the grown - up people voices were so harsh ; the accent was so hideous .

[They]1267-the children burst out again :

[Chree]147-chree to gay ei , [Geeray]148-geeray didax . . . .

Then [they]1267-the children stopped . It seemed to be in the middle of a verse . [They]1267-the children stood there grinning , silent , looking at the floor . [Nobody]690-nobody knew what to say . There was something horrible in the noise [they]1267-the children made . It was so shrill , so discordant , and so meaningless . Then [old Patrick]118-patrick ambled up .

" Ah , that 's very nice , that 's very nice . Thank [you]1271-the grown - up people , [[my]118-patrick dears]1852-my dears , "[118-patrick] [he]118-patrick said in [his]118-patrick genial way , fiddling with [his]118-patrick toothpick . [The children]1267-the children grinned at [him]118-patrick . Then [they]1267-the children began to make off . As [they]1267-the children sidled past [Martin]88-martin , [he]118-patrick slipped coins into [their]1267-the children hands . Then [they]1267-the children made a dash for the door .

" But what the devil were [they]1267-the children singing ? "[106-hugh] said [Hugh Gibbs]106-hugh . " [I]106-hugh could n't understand a word of it , [I]106-hugh must confess . "[106-hugh] [He]106-hugh held [his]106-hugh hands to the sides of [his]106-hugh large white waistcoat .

" Cockney accent , [I]118-patrick suppose , "[118-patrick] said [Patrick]118-patrick . " What [they]1267-the children teach 'em at [school]1066-school , [you]46-eleanor know . "[118-patrick]

" But it was . . . "[46-eleanor] [Eleanor]46-eleanor began . [She]46-eleanor stopped . What was it ? As [they]1267-the children stood there [they]1267-the children had looked so dignified ; yet [they]1267-the children had made this hideous noise . The contrast between [their]1267-the children faces and [their]1267-the children voices was astonishing ; it was impossible to find one word for the whole . " Beautiful ? "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor said , with a note of interrogation , turning to [Maggie]52-peggy .

" Extraordinarily , "[52-peggy] said [Maggie]52-peggy .

But [Eleanor]46-eleanor was not sure that [they]1267-the children were thinking of the same thing .

[She]46-eleanor gathered together [her]46-eleanor gloves , [her]46-eleanor bag and two or three coppers , and got up . [The room]261-the room was full of a queer pale light . [Objects]149-objects seemed to be rising out of [their]149-objects sleep , out of [their]149-objects disguise , and to be assuming the sobriety of daily life . [The room]261-the room was making ready for [its]261-the room use as [[an estate agent]1279-an estate agent 's office]1280-an estate agent 's office . The tables were becoming office tables ; [their]1281-their legs were the legs of [office tables]1282-office tables , and yet they were still strewn with plates and glasses , with roses , lilies and carnations .

" It 's time to go , "[46-eleanor] [she]46-eleanor said , crossing [the room]261-the room . [Delia]68-delia had gone to the window . Now [she]68-delia jerked the curtains open .

" The dawn ! "[68-delia] [she]68-delia exclaimed rather melodramatically .

The shapes of [houses]460-houses appeared across [the square]504-the square . [Their]460-houses blinds were all drawn ; [they]460-houses seemed fast asleep still in the morning pallor .

" The dawn ! "[53-nicholas] said [Nicholas]53-nicholas , getting up and stretching [himself]53-nicholas . [He]53-nicholas too walked across to the window . [Renny]71-renny followed [him]53-nicholas .

" But the dawn has risen , "[71-renny] said [Renny]71-renny , pointing at the sky .

It was a fact . The sun had risen . The sky between the chimneys looked extraordinarily blue .

" And [I]53-nicholas am going to bed , "[53-nicholas] said [Nicholas]53-nicholas after a pause . [He]53-nicholas turned away .

There were the smeared plates , and the empty wine - glasses ; the petals and the bread crumbs . In the mixture of lights [they]1290-they looked prosaic but unreal ; cadaverous but brilliant . " Not on a fine summer morning , "[88-martin] said [Martin]88-martin .

A breeze went through [the square]504-the square . In the stillness [they]1303-you could hear the branches rustle as they rose slightly , and fell , and shook a wave of green light through the air .

Then the door burst open . [Couple after couple]1304-couple after couple came flocking in , dishevelled , gay , to look for [their]1304-couple after couple cloaks and [their]1304-couple after couple hats , to say good - night .

[THE END]1316-the end
